title: MG and the Benefits of Napping

content: Imagine feeling guilty about resting. That was my experience adjusting to life with a chronic illness.

Before my myasthenia gravis (MG) diagnosis, I stayed in a constant state of productivity. When my body couldn’t keep that same pace, I was devastated. I felt guilty about taking a nap. It was as though I believed the world would fall apart if I took 30 minutes to rest. It wasn’t until later in my journey that I discovered napping isn’t a luxury, but a crucial component of managing a chronic illness.
In this post, we’ll discuss how naps can enhance your quality of life and how to overcome nap guilt.

There are several benefits to napping when you have a chronic illness. For starters, naps are great for energy restoration. Both physical and mental energy can be replenished when you nap. You can improve your focus and mental clarity to help with brain fog.

Pain management is another benefit. Engaging in naps can cause muscle relaxation and reduce your overall discomfort. There are also mental health and mood benefits. Napping can lower your stress levels, which positively impacts your illness symptoms.

content: Napping is a positive for both your brain and body. Did you know there are different kinds of naps with different benefits? They include:
Power nap. (10-20 minutes). These are good for boosting your alertness and energy quickly.
Short nap . (30 minutes). This nap enhances your overall brain function.
Long nap. (60-90 minutes). This promotes creativity and memory function.
No matter the length of your naps, they improve the function of your brain and body.

Overcoming nap guilt is something I work at every day. I believe it’s partly due to the stigma around napping. Generally, napping is seen as laziness. I felt guilty about resting at one point because I didn’t want to be viewed as lazy or not trying hard enough.
I thought that if I took a nap, I wouldn't be productive. But I’ve changed how I define productivity. Instead of having the mindset of “Go-go-go,” I try to remember it’s okay to “Go-stop-go later.”

content: Taking time to rest is being productive. I remember that it’s OK to stop and pick up tasks at a later time. I call this strategic rest. This can lead to better outcomes, especially if you’re living with a condition like MG.

Overall, napping is a legitimate and beneficial practice in your self-care routine. It can restore your physical and mental energy and aid with pain management. It can also lower your stress levels, which, in turn, can improve your illness symptoms.

I view taking a nap the same way I view taking my medications – it’s a requirement. I encourage you to reshape your views on rest and indulge in guilt-free napping moving forward. Your body and mind will thank you for it.
